Description: Rim sherd of Attic black-figured pottery Siana cup; interior: reserved band just below rim, glazed (fired brown) below; black band on top of rim; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of head and upper body of beardless rider to left; at right, tail feathers of a bird flying to right.
Producer name: Attributed to: The C Painter (Shadow of (Beazley))
Curator's comments: Beazley attributes this sherd to the Shadow of the C Painter, describing the work as almost indistinguishable from the C Painter, but drier and more listless (Beazley ABV, 51). Beazley also suggests that should this sherd be the work of the C Painter, and that it might come from one of his later pieces. Brijder describes the Taras Painter's faces for youths and men as 'having pronounced profiles with protruding noses, receding mouths, and prominent chins' (Brijder 1983, 163). For parallels, compare Taranto I.G. 4442, side B (Brijder 1983, pl. 16b, no. 52).
Bibliographic references: Brijder 1983a / Siana Cups I and Komast Cups (p. 253, no. 180)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 371, no. B503)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 229, no. 4)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0392) (Phase 1)
